text: Catharine Macaulay (2 April 1731 â€“ 22 June 1791) was an English historian. Between 1763 and 1783 Macaulay wrote her biggest work, The History of England from the Accession of James I to that of the Brunswick Line. Her 1790 work Letters on Education deeply influenced Mary Wollstonecraft. ==Early life== Macaulay was born Catharine Sawbridge at Olantigh in Kent. She had two brothers. She was educated by a governess. ==Personal life== Macaulay married her first husband George Macaulay on 18 June 1760. In 1766, he died. In 1774, she moved to Bath. In 1788, Macaulay married William Graham. Macaulay died in Binfield in 1791. ==References== Category:1731 births Category:1791 deaths Category:English historians Category:Writers from Kent
title: Catharine Macaulay
